document.title: AP®  Psychology COURSE AND EXAM DESCRIPTION

23AC3C3BD710415989E9968E30075FE8.description:
Surgical or invasive interventions include
psychosurgery (which may involve lesioning),
TMS (transcranial magnetic stimulation), or
electroconvulsive therapy. The lobotomy is
a form of psychosurgery that was popular
in the mid-20th century but is rarely, if ever,
performed today.

BFC1A70C3DB141DF8A351B419532DAA6.description:
Psychoactive medications, such as
antidepressants, antianxiety drugs, lithium,
or antipsychotic medications, interact with
specific neurotransmitters in the central
nervous system to address possible
biochemical causes of mental disorders.
Psychoactive medications can have side
effects such as tardive dyskinesia (a movement
disorder related to the regulation of dopamine
in the nervous system).

96DA76BC025D46EDB0C165B0A684ECB0.description:
Describe interventions
derived from the biological
perspective.

D5F44AC122384CDAB11F06507B10DA6C.description:
Hypnosis has shown effectiveness in treating
pain and anxiety. Research does not support
the use of hypnosis to retrieve accurate
memories or regress in age.

12D76E45301840E0B57A6E856724FD54.description:
There are no required essential knowledge
statements for this learning objective.

4058585D5A9F48CD832FE410829B45A2.description:
Explain how group therapy
is different from individual
therapy.

2D400FC9769A47108DCB0E0DC3FB0B3C.description:
Therapy from the humanistic perspective,
commonly referred to as person-centered
therapy, employs active listening and
unconditional positive regard.

75D8B925443440878B2FAC65AA23B64D.description:
Cognitive-behavioral therapies, such as
dialectical behavior therapy and rationalemotive behavior therapy, combine techniques
from the cognitive and behavioral perspectives
to treat mental and behavioral disorders.

2B125EC6FD3841008A3979A53ECBEEC7.description:
Applied behavior analysis involves applying
principles of conditioning to address mental
disorders and developmental disabilities.
Exposure therapies (such as systematic
desensitization), aversion therapies, and token
economies all employ principles of applied
behavior analysis. Biofeedback uses principles
of conditioning to help clients regulate
body systems (such as the sympathetic and
parasympathetic nervous systems) that
contribute to feelings of anxiety or depression.

A43072F0C0894D078E6904C94C33844C.description:
Cognitive therapies may employ cognitive
restructuring or fear hierarchies to combat
maladaptive thinking. Cognitive therapy
proposes that people should focus on the
cognitive triad—negative thoughts about
oneself, the world, and the future.

26055AA163B240C7B568D555D953CBB9.description:
Psychodynamic therapies employ free
association and dream interpretation to
uncover the unconscious mind.

104BED0ABD59431EA0EAB58B978C82C9.description:
Describe techniques used
with psychological therapies.

B65B375D3CF44AFBA4F2CD7E6F399CBF.description:
Psychologists in clinical or therapeutic
situations must follow certain ethical
principles as established by the APA, including
nonmaleficence, fidelity, integrity, and respect
for people’s rights and dignity.

96D1A4F9DBD545E2A6C52D4BE1507010.description:
Describe ethical principles
in the treatment of
psychological disorders.

C5F7958425484902AFA47F987B0936F1.description:
Due to the increased use and effectiveness of
psychotropic medication therapy, hospitals and
asylums deinstitutionalized massive numbers
of people in the late 20th century. Therapists
now prefer to treat in decentralized ways,
often with a combination of medication and
psychological therapies.

B4C2B3599F584D7F884981DC11ACD948.description:
Describe research and
trends in the treatment of
psychological disorders.

0A9A11BEE885433EB49084C7033EFA14.description:
Many researchers who have conducted metaanalytic studies of psychotherapy conclude
that psychotherapies are generally effective.
Many psychologists use evidence-based
interventions to develop treatment plans.
Therapists should exhibit cultural humility and
establish a therapeutic alliance with the client
to deliver therapy successfully.

79E2E2E68EBE4AEB954559C6D4B2533E.description:
Describe research and
trends in the treatment of
psychological disorders.

B2AE0C083F71496580BC3209F0B49DEC.description:
Possible causes of personality disorders
focus on biological, genetic, social, cultural,
behavioral, or cognitive sources.

445EFC1D7D43424EB10805B61E9E7AAB.description:
Cluster C is the anxious or fearful cluster
and includes avoidant, dependent,
and obsessive-compulsive personality
disorders.

5EC05EADF6224528A298E56F540E69FD.description:
Cluster B is the dramatic, emotional, or
erratic cluster and includes antisocial,
histrionic, narcissistic, and borderline
personality disorders.

09FBA18539A74050BA73A2CBB2816861.description:
Cluster A is the odd or eccentric cluster
and includes paranoid, schizoid, and
schizotypal personality disorders.

A4C0CB62F5824393918FCAB6F8AB3F3E.description:
Personality disorders (which fall into three
clusters) are characterized by enduring
patterns of internal experience and behavior
that is deviant from one’s culture; is pervasive
and inflexible; begins in adolescence or early
adulthood; is stable over time; and leads to
personal distress or impairment.

06EBF9EFE04C429089DAA9A6ADD45595.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
personality disorders.

EDBA26C83DDF487FA14ACFC53EE297CE.description:
Possible causes of feeding and eating
disorders focus on biological, genetic, social,
cultural, behavioral, or cognitive sources.

C29D14CD79C74DD48C84B72A731E4EBF.description:
Feeding and eating disorders are characterized
by altered consumption or absorption of food
that impairs health or psychological functioning.

6A5C04EC68D749A9AA108DB2D0B2A4E6.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
feeding and eating disorders.

3888F27197D04FA38A4CED2FD5B58BAF.description:
Possible causes of trauma and stressor-related
disorders involve the experience of trauma or
stress.

AC5A792A79C44D3EBEAD3B071EEDF37E.description:
Trauma and stressor-related disorders are
characterized by exposure to a traumatic or
stressful event with subsequent psychological
distress. Symptoms of trauma and stressorrelated disorders may involve hypervigilance,
severe anxiety, flashbacks to traumatic or
stressful experiences, insomnia, emotional
detachment, and hostility.

A11534E1021A431F98831951EA3AA791.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
trauma and stressor-related
disorders.

28D1C87CC7CD42D6843884B864C2A465.description:
Possible causes of dissociative disorders
involve the experience of trauma or stress.

2A290932F6E041D395FB9F4E900D9A46.description:
Dissociative disorders are characterized
by dissociations from consciousness,
memory, identity, emotion, perception, body
representation, motor control, and behavior.

A20ABEA983AB46B69FA8CBF28373E44C.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
dissociative disorders.

CA03CC6525E4422586CEE66AD1BE98B2.description:
Possible causes of obsessive-compulsive
disorders involve learned associations
between and among stimuli, maladaptive
thinking or emotional responses, and biological
or genetic sources.

624E8F0ACF324829A8B9B1B740F55B78.description:
Obsessive-compulsive and related
disorders are characterized by the presence
of obsessions (intrusive thoughts) and
compulsions (intrusive, often repetitive,
behaviors intended to address obsessions).

A2D7975D1D1A4DCCBE62023996445F63.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
obsessive-compulsive
disorders and related
disorders.

BCC2BB481F6C4A75AB6B2D7598350276.description:
Possible causes of anxiety disorders focus
on learned associations between and among
stimuli, maladaptive thinking or emotional
responses, and biological or genetic sources.

034B01F7E67C42DAB10113F3BF09D4AE.description:
Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) involves
prolonged experiences of nonspecific
anxiety or fear.

E4A37070671147C4A2EAFFCE1AE6686A.description:
Social anxiety disorder involves the intense
fear of being judged or watched by others.
Social anxiety disorder is distinct from but
may include agoraphobia. Taijin kyofusho is a
culture-bound anxiety disorder experienced
mainly by Japanese people in which people
fear others are judging their bodies as
undesirable, offensive, or unpleasing.

9169331081704E81AFD363C59A361597.description:
Panic disorder involves the experience
of panic attacks (unanticipated and
overwhelming biological, cognitive, and
emotional experiences of fear/anxiety).
Panic disorder can manifest as a culturebound anxiety disorder such as ataque de
nervios (experienced mainly by people of
Caribbean or Iberian descent).

9238F6C89CF44BE387351B36EA0A2762.description:
Agoraphobia is intense fear of specific
social situations, including using public
transportation, being in open spaces, being
in enclosed spaces (e.g., shops, theaters,
etc.), standing in line or being in a crowd, or
being outside of the home alone.

8305E220ACF441568F7AC9661894649F.description:
Specific phobia involves fear or anxiety
toward a specific object or situation, such
as acrophobia (heights) or arachnophobia
(spiders).

35D953841A204888B724C704D4D2EF72.description:
Anxiety disorders are characterized by
excessive fear and/or anxiety with related
disturbances to behavior.

0CCE8BD49ED74BACA99B89D97E09FB88.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
anxiety disorders.

4C5A0F088CFF48428068B40A3BEC19CD.description:
Possible causes of bipolar disorders focus on
biological, genetic, social, cultural, behavioral,
or cognitive sources.

5224122B4A144EE8B34C9A0DF95707A1.description:
Bipolar disorders are characterized by periods
of mania and periods of depression. Bipolar
cycling involves experiencing periods of
depression and mania in alternating periods
that can last various amounts of time.

6B9748AFC29649F391BEFDA4782E2BD1.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
bipolar disorders.

B2DE725877B543BAA75F92F04F6DB4B6.description:
Possible causes of depressive disorders
focus on biological, genetic, social, cultural,
behavioral, or cognitive sources.

A3B74B981A7843168081202D9F8A2FEE.description:
Depressive disorders are characterized by the
presence of sad, empty, or irritable mood along
with physical and cognitive changes that affect
a person’s ability to function.

731727565B4B4F80803EEAE7A4E048DB.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
depressive disorders.

8AE53BC7E043481DACA57CAD3A27377D.description:
Possible causes of schizophrenia suggest
a genetic or biological link, such as prenatal
virus exposure or imbalances with certain
neurotransmitters (dopamine hypothesis).

B1A85E5BDA6C475296675C7DCCC64E2C.description:
Negative symptoms present as the lack
of a typical behavior, such as the lack of
emotional expression (flat affect) or lack of
movement (catatonic stupor).

F62A968E0DFA4038BE79E12F61F8332A.description:
Disorganized motor behavior may
manifest as catatonia. Catatonia, or
disordered movement, may be experienced
as excitement (a positive symptom
manifestation) or stupor (a negative
symptom manifestation).

DB88BACA537743CEA8CFB4AEF29501BE.description:
Disorganized thinking or speech is a
positive symptom and may manifest as
speaking in ways such as speaking in a
word salad (stringing together words in
nonsensical ways).

3B1D9AC63E9D4141A747322494EE333D.description:
Hallucinations (false perceptions) are
positive symptoms and may involve one or
more of the senses.

B162424EBEE147E59B8310983175D64A.description:
Delusions (false beliefs) are positive
symptoms and may manifest in ways such
as delusions of persecution or grandeur.

AD93EE104A034F839A72C31319CAEF1F.description:
Schizophrenic spectrum disorders are
characterized by issues in one or more of these
five areas: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized
thinking or speech, disorganized motor behavior,
and negative symptoms. Schizophrenia can be
experienced as an acute or chronic condition.

1325113686E0450783FFCBD5AC2F2EC4.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
schizophrenic spectrum
disorders.

DFDB62C8BDE547A3AA0B939465029C5C.description:
Possible causes of neurodevelopmental
disorders may be environmental, physiological,
or genetic in nature.

F17B59D0EFB44A33B581C40DDFEE33DA.description:
Neurodevelopmental disorders are a group
of disorders with onset occurring during
the developmental period. Symptoms of
neurodevelopmental disorders focus on
whether the person is exhibiting behaviors
appropriate for their age or maturity range.

5B5FCC031A8E41F3AE42D40FC5587CDE.description:
Describe the symptoms and
possible causes of selected
neurodevelopmental
disorders.

CE69C4A391764ADD92ECC4AA3A6454F5.description:
Selection of Categories
of Psychological
Disorders

72266C889BDC4DCC9A9DCBA4D7E01DBA.description:
The diathesis-stress model assumes that
psychological disorders develop due to a
genetic vulnerability (diathesis) in combination
with stressful life experiences (stress).

69CB267F7F47416FAC66F4EA1CEDA427.description:
The biopsychosocial model assumes that any
psychological problem potentially involves a
combination of biological, psychological, and
sociocultural factors.

82983060A6504254823540FD42621BC6.description:
Explain how interaction
models define psychological
disorders.

0D51E761E4B54D75A5DBF75FEE6C8895.description:
The biological perspective proposes that
the causes of mental disorders focus on
physiological or genetic issues.

17447CDBEB114E96B70B05C61492DF08.description:
The sociocultural perspective proposes that
the causes of mental disorders focus on
maladaptive social and cultural relationships
and dynamics.

0EAE961A35414A3891C604C9B493B3E2.description:
The evolutionary perspective proposes that
the causes of mental disorders focus on
behaviors and mental processes that reduce
the likelihood of survival.

194C2BE14BBC4E4AB0045007FDD02A04.description:
The cognitive perspective proposes that
the causes of mental disorders focus on
maladaptive thoughts, beliefs, attitudes, or
emotions.

0AC42EC4892746A49C20E291AC681FF6.description:
The humanistic perspective proposes that the
causes of mental disorders focus on a lack of
social support and being unable to fulfill one’s
potential.

9BA440A331D342B4B759A52A3B1105E9.description:
The psychodynamic perspective proposes
that the causes of mental disorders focus on
unconscious thoughts and experiences, often
developed during childhood.

F545549F1C594FCEB94EF8CA21666B66.description:
The behavioral perspective proposes that
the causes of mental disorders focus on
maladaptive learned associations between or
among responses to stimuli.

0C399CC538CA4E1A9AB019EA200A7D8E.description:
Most psychologists employ an eclectic
approach (using more than one psychological
perspective) when diagnosing and treating
clients.

1B40218E93574356B464F6154ACAF032.description:
Explain how psychological
perspectives define
psychological disorders.

D70775D3531943708EAAB72E96707811.description:
Diagnosing psychological disorders requires
specialized training and the use of evidencebased diagnostic tools. The American
Psychiatric Association developed the
Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM) of
Mental Disorders to classify mental disorders.
The World Health Organization developed the
International Classification of Mental Disorders
(ICD) to classify mental disorders. These
classification systems are updated regularly
to be responsive to new research and practice
advances.

338C6D2DD41A4B63B389A171F4C76D1F.description:
Diagnosing or classifying psychological
disorders has positive and negative
consequences depending on the nature of the
disorder, the individual being diagnosed, and
the presence of cultural/societal norms, stigma,
racism, sexism, ageism, and discrimination.

84B0B6D87323401CABC109A72AB4124D.description:
Level of dysfunction, perception of distress,
and deviation from the social norm are
all factors used to identify psychological
disorders.

D1E29E7B36C74EB1A0CBB81D277465DF.description:
Describe the approaches
used to define behaviors
and mental processes as
psychological disorders.

D6E80315310C4577B5E325562470A3E0.description:
Posttraumatic growth, a positive subjective
experience, may result after the experience of
trauma or stress.

DB689FF16F9C4CA6A2390CFD4E271E58.description:
People who exercise their signature strengths
or virtues report higher levels of positive
objective experiences such as happiness
and subjective well-being. A classification
of character strengths has been developed
around 6 categories of virtues: wisdom,
courage, humanity, justice, temperance, and
transcendence.

5A7C6649B7704CBBA6E6E6969521F082.description:
Expressing gratitude, a positive subjective
experience, increases subjective well-being.

4519F53D71254EDFB9F5A7D62384659E.description:
Explain how positive
subjective experiences
apply to behavior and mental
processes.

FDFB0F42910C4433BD96D505426CC41C.description:
Positive psychology seeks to identify factors
that lead to well-being, resilience, positive
emotions, and psychological health.

B69680F3B5324527A8274E39BF175458.description:
Explain how positive
psychology approaches the
study of behavior and mental
processes.

DABE560076A8480FB889DCA302685E89.description:
Emotion-focused coping involves managing
emotional reactions to stress as a means of
coping. Strategies that are emotion-focused
may include deep breathing, meditation, or
taking medication aimed at reducing stressful
emotional responses.

BA4DF9B245DA40F883FFED5F35183D18.description:
Problem-focused coping involves seeing
stress as a problem to be solved and working
solutions until a solution is found.

960B9B599DB34668AF3E61FBA7BA4563.description:
Explain how the ways that
people cope with stress
applies to behavior and
mental processes.

A597F6528CDB4E0F8C7EED0857B08468.description:
The tend-and-befriend theory proposes that
some people react to stress by tending to
their own needs and/or the needs of others
and seeking connection with others. This
phenomenon seems to occur mostly in women.

E849BA2043BF428092CF467CFF17828B.description:
The general adaptation syndrome (GAS)
describes the process of experiencing
stress. Initially, alarm reaction occurs when
the stress is encountered. Then, a resistance
phase occurs as the stress is confronted
(via a fight-flight-freeze response). Finally, an
exhaustion phase occurs when the stress
subsides, or resources are spent. The greatest
susceptibility to illness occurs during the
exhaustion phase.

BC577C46175E4C6990D9D2FA871D1FAE.description:
Explain how reactions to
stress apply to behavior and
mental processes.

5018A44D09A146A9AFE9A0B772A31193.description:
Stressors can be viewed as motivating
(eustress) or debilitating (distress). Stressors
can be experienced as traumatic or as daily
hassles that can build up over time. Adverse
childhood experiences (ACEs) are sources of
stress that can affect a person throughout the
lifespan.

BA3AFFEE9CB94604AFEFCF982D932205.description:
Stress is a factor in heightened susceptibility to
disorders and disease. Stress has been linked
to physiological issues such as hypertension,
headaches, and immune suppression.

BB4DC229C4EE4443B52D619C9B9A2377.description:
Explain how stress applies
to behavior and mental
processes.

0C27C2F2ADB1423A80721DFE9977B361.description:
There are no required essential knowledge
statements for this learning objective.

34ECF1772BF5483B925D87F73D641D77.description:
Explain how health
psychology addresses
issues of physical health
and wellness as they apply
to behavior and mental
processes.

873C942C759E487A8BE5553925FD29DD.description:
Display rules and elicitors for emotional
expression can differ among cultures.
Display rules and elicitors may regulate how
people from different genders, ages, or
socioeconomic classes within a culture can
display and interpret emotions.

1C977EDBE261408FB65CE0E6F07DF4E0.description:
Research has explored whether the expression
of emotions is universally common. Some
emotions that may be commonly experienced
across cultures include anger, disgust,
sadness, happiness, surprise, and fear.
Research on the universality of emotions
shows mixed results.

B31F4396B8B24695990263D3EDF4F111.description:
Explain how social norms and
experiences influence the
expression of emotions.

61442374B6C043DA9048CB6B52448439.description:
The broaden-and-build theory of emotion
proposes that positive emotional experiences
tend to broaden awareness and encourage
new actions and thoughts. Negative emotions
tend to reduce awareness and narrow thinking
and action.

2EEA9BEC10174C9CB94DF092AA8B9593.description:
Emotion, or affect, is a complex psychological
process that is distinguished from reasoning
or knowledge. Emotions reflect internal
and external factors affecting an individual.
Early 20th century psychological theories
of emotion parsed the distinction between
the physiological and cognitive experiences
of emotion. Some theories proposed that
the physiological and cognitive experiences
occurred in succession while others proposed
that they occurred simultaneously. Other
theories emphasize that the cognitive label
is required to experience an emotion. The
facial-feedback hypothesis suggests that
the experience of emotion is influenced by
facial expressions, which supports theories
that propose the physiological experience of
emotion precedes the cognitive appraisal, and
research testing this hypothesis has produced
mixed results.

762BD4DDAA644A749B036F3C2ACE861A.description:
Explain how theories of
emotion apply to behavior
and mental processes.

C9666FE779984116961ADA2D03678CB9.description:
External factors like the presence of food,
time of day, or social gatherings around
meals also influence the behavior of eating.

A542353F457B45C0AE946925F4B3E579.description:
Hormones, such as ghrelin and leptin
(regulated by the hypothalamus via the
pituitary gland), regulate feelings of hunger
and satiety.

1CFC8E621A134C3BA284C1D477815654.description:
Eating is a complex motivated behavior that
demonstrates how physical and mental
processes interact.

0A2D8BAD309842E58616E2837CAFE306.description:
Explain how eating and
belongingness motivate
behavior and mental
processes.

1079128D49314C05892C8C5622B79068.description:
Sensation-seeking theory proposes that one’s
level of need for varied or novel experiences is
the basis of motivation. The types of sensation
seeking are experience seeking, thrill or
adventure seeking, disinhibition, and boredom
susceptibility.

268373D458B146DDAD7AD033E5A98763.description:
Lewin’s motivational conflicts theory proposes
that choices create conflicts one must resolve
as the basis of motivation. The type of conflicts
faced include approach-approach, approachavoidance, and avoidance-avoidance.

E165BEB3C56941CC82F4BB3C7452FEC6.description:
Many non-human animals are motivated by
instincts (innate, typically fixed patterns of
behavior in animals in response to certain
stimuli). Humans do not seem to demonstrate
instinctual behavior or mental processes.

3EB9F95949BA4689B6D4E6C57C26D100.description:
Self-determination theory proposes that
people are motivated by intrinsic (internal)
or extrinsic (external) motivations. Incentive
theory explores the role of rewards (an extrinsic
motivation) in motivating behavior.

8EAD7301952D41EFB56E0ACDBC3F395B.description:
Some theories about motivation focus on
behavior and mental processes that seek to
address physical needs and desires such as
drive-reduction theory and arousal theory.
Drive-reduction theory addresses how certain
behaviors help maintain homeostasis while
arousal theory addresses how people seek an
optimal level of arousal when they behave (as
demonstrated by the Yerkes-Dodson Law).

617B860C44AA471A8555862E15880079.description:
Explain how theories about
motivation apply to behavior
and mental processes.

335E7796108A4C40B8B7287AA1B13023.description:
The Big Five theory of personality proposes
that traits of agreeableness, openness to
experience, extraversion, conscientiousness,
and emotional stability make up one’s
personality. These traits are measured by
specialized personality inventories that use
factor analysis to organize item responses.

A59A2A1075EE4A99AC4037BFE18942C0.description:
Trait theories of personality conclude
that personality involves a set of enduring
characteristics that lead to typical responses
to stimuli.

6D46E304D58243F8B03E90BFCCFB4D13.description:
Explain how trait theories of
personality define and assess
personality.

86C4107F78A64C9793BF273B38EF264B.description:
According to social-cognitive theory, reciprocal
determinism shapes personality. Reciprocal
determinism explores self-concept (how one
views themselves and in relation to others)
and how self-efficacy and self-esteem both
contribute to self-concept.

D2D3EF9C92AD4B2E976251334FD589E9.description:
Explain how the socialcognitive theory of
personality defines and
assesses personality.

6111D02F5B824BADB2D30640F321A9F8.description:
Social-Cognitive
and Trait Theories
of Personality

D3D1B6B5EE2348EB8541969BDC8171E2.description:
According to humanistic psychology,
personality focuses on unconditional regard
and the self-actualizing tendency as primary
motivating factors.

DB8E80891D034AE59668F322077E48D1.description:
Explain how the humanistic
theory of personality defines
and assesses personality.

2135096EEB434C689BBCAA6DF8E24D8E.description:
Psychodynamic personality psychologists
assess personality using projective tests that
are designed to probe the preconscious and
unconscious mind.

EC3EDB0CA42A40638B3BEEC471549ED3.description:
Ego defense mechanisms (denial,
displacement, projection, rationalization,
reaction formation, regression, repression,
and sublimation) serve to protect the ego
unconsciously from threats.

D30776EAC2F142D8A32E865BCA14C87F.description:
According to the psychodynamic theory of
personality, unconscious processes drive
personality.

D2EC76F4835141FF9F3A0AEC0707AF84.description:
Explain how the
psychodynamic theory of
personality defines and
assesses personality.

2C5B7B8726264A10B3A57BA23E9C528D.description:
Psychodynamic and
Humanistic Theories
of Personality

E46BBF5D4CF24BC7B81D648585C8F293.description:
The bystander effect demonstrates that
situational and attentional variables predict
whether someone is likely to help another
person.

76266BC2D0224E8E98FB6ED0F5D7AD73.description:
Altruism refers to selfless behavior, but
some researchers suggest that people act
in prosocial ways due to incurring social
debt. The social reciprocity norm and the
social responsibility norm explain this type of
behavior.

4FBC98A34DBD46B7AFB3A21B759CCE36.description:
Explain how prosocial
behavior affects behavior
and mental processes.

FB6D470223914102937F1DE8E361A1DD.description:
Industrial-organizational (I/O) psychologists
study how people perform in the workplace.
I/O psychologists study best practices in
management of work, relationships among
people working together or for a common
company or program, and how people feel
about work (burnout).

2B1DE90E60FA485CBDB2D6F61D22E3B0.description:
Superordinate goals serve to unite disparate
groups under a common goal and help reduce
negative affect and stereotyping among
groups. Social traps occur when individuals do
not unite and act in their own self-interest to
the detriment of the group.

57186211BDAE48D4BFF6958633A673E4.description:
People often overestimate the levels to which
others agree with them, known as the false
consensus effect.

93198D982FDB42468B12BDF50E7883E2.description:
Performing a mental or physical behavior in
front of a group can lead to social facilitation.

4C0F0976DF19423380F49C1859E28D94.description:
Being a member of a group can influence
how one behaves or experiences mental
processes via group polarization, groupthink,
diffusion of responsibility, social loafing, and
deindividuation.

BF1A4C26BE9046ADAC98B35C3D78E31C.description:
Cultural phenomena such as individualism,
collectivism, and multiculturalism can influence
how one perceives and behaves toward oneself
and others.

72ED2268CAB442079A9CB665ACD4A2FC.description:
Explain how being in a group
can affect an individual’s
behavior and mental
processes.

DEF078E481AF4121A4CE2696B2A80074.description:
Research on obedience clarifies the conditions
that strengthen the likelihood of people
complying with the directives of an authority
figure.

CDC9AD660E2E493192954E429D9216AF.description:
Research on conformity clarifies the
conditions that strengthen the likelihood of
people adhering to unspoken rules, norms, or
expectations.

E408472F2B7447EC8EB4B013F3DAA0F5.description:
Persuasion can depend on how information
is presented, as demonstrated by the
foot-in-the-door and the door-in-the-face
techniques.

169EB808128F4EE69359BCE3288378E6.description:
Persuasion can depend on the route to
persuasion. The elaboration likelihood model
outlines two main routes to persuasion:
central and peripheral. The halo effect is an
example of a peripheral route to persuasion.

6CF3F83CF53E4828B25AC8B39B6417D1.description:
Persuasion refers to the techniques applied to
convince the self or others of particular ideas,
actions, or beliefs.

9387896A41384C7F8CA4EBB2103EAE09.description:
Social influence theory proposes that social
pressure to behave or think in certain ways can
be normative or informational.

7B4D903A4BB842DB941D81DCA2C28DDB.description:
Social norms define expectations and roles a
society may have for its members in individual
and social situations.

403617B795384D81B06015E80BB311B2.description:
Explain how the social
situation affects behavior and
mental processes.

AB91D321E26648A384E2970F5FE15B4B.description:
Cognitive dissonance refers to the mental
discomfort that occurs when actions or
attitudes are in conflict. People are motivated
to reduce the discomfort by changing either
actions or attitudes to be more in line with
each other.

A985D42AE09C42CAB965432F56FECBC1.description:
Belief perseverance occurs when a belief
persists even if evidence suggests it is
not accurate. People experiencing belief
perseverance may engage in confirmation
bias, thereby clinging to an attitude or belief
regardless of the evidence for or against it.

97E81274E3F24F12ACDEBF359E694DE9.description:
Explain how belief
perseverance and cognitive
dissonance apply to attitude
formation and change.

97E1EB6B0FE648A88CDEE792A5A4BE67.description:
Implicit attitudes are those that individuals
hold but may be unaware of or may not
acknowledge. Research has focused on how
implicit attitudes reflect negative evaluations
of others, as demonstrated by the just-world
phenomenon, out-group homogeneity bias, ingroup bias, or ethnocentrism.

041CDF46934E4F039D48E13BFAF7DC98.description:
A stereotype is a generalized concept about a
group. Stereotypes can help reduce cognitive
load when making decisions or judgments.
Stereotypes can be the cause and/or result of
biased perceptions and experiences and are
frequently the basis of prejudiced attitudes and
discriminatory behaviors.

35B8BB10515B49DCA52BF1D5C74FEE12.description:
Explain how stereotypes and
implicit attitudes contribute
to the behaviors and mental
processes of prejudice and
discrimination.

C0FDC2C8BFA944A0A07CAF435A39A0F3.description:
Social comparison is a type of person
perception that occurs when people evaluate
themselves based on comparisons to other
members of society or social circles. Social
comparison can be upward or downward.
People often judge their own sense of
deprivation relative to others (relative
deprivation).

C7BA4339EDD24B91BA84B69F9BFA6718.description:
People can behave in ways that elicit behaviors
from others that confirm their beliefs or
perceptions about themselves or others (selffulfilling prophecy).

115BBC682AF046889E87D87F6699C300.description:
People’s perception of how much they like
something can be influenced by the mere
exposure effect. The mere exposure effect
occurs when people are exposed to a stimulus
repeatedly over time, which causes them to like
the stimulus more.

51101ADB480F464080266F1DF8ECBC11.description:
Explain how person
perception applies to
behavior and mental
processes.

20DF528BF9624758B83AC2FB44F03F0B.description:
There are no required essential knowledge
statements for this learning objective.

9D1BC5A20CE24377972DBC58BA10B57F.description:
Explain how locus of control
(internal and external) applies
to behavior and mental
processes.

A72ACB4EC0C540EC8F211E38EFB198FD.description:
People are subject to biases in their
attributions. Those biases include actor/
observer bias, fundamental attribution error,
and self-serving bias, all of which can affect
behavior and mental processes.

1A3FD7DB5FD845DCB5B4E57CE0D5BD67.description:
People demonstrate a predictable pattern of
attributions called explanatory style. Explanatory
style is how people explain good and bad events
in their lives and in the lives of others. Explanatory
style can be optimistic or pessimistic.

FF75C8225F4D4B5EB8171B079FC28FB3.description:
Attributions are how people explain behavior
and mental processes of themselves and
others. Dispositional attributions relate to
internal qualities of others (such as intelligence
or personality) while situational attributions
relate to external circumstances that are
experienced.

60351D5EA62A4A3382C8B0D364CF7EF5.description:
Explain how attribution
theory applies to behavior
and mental processes.

10CE20E532DD416E88CA119A88C32403.description:
Latent learning occurs when information
is learned without reinforcement but is not
immediately evident. Latent learning is often
demonstrated by cognitive maps.

32553C23944443648A4CF96613D42D02.description:
Insight learning occurs when the solution to
a problem occurs without any association,
consequence, or model being present.

E78AF4EF736E4D88B9F0C6A7457FDDFE.description:
Explain how cognitive factors
in learning apply to behavior
and mental processes.

276F042667C1495CB538EBE3528E5C25.description:
Social learning theory proposes that learning
can occur by observation and does not
have to involve personal experience with a
consequence (vicarious conditioning). Learning
can occur by copying the behavior of models.
The more similar a model is, the more likely the
behavior is to be learned.

4643F67FA2F644049D585CD9501774E3.description:
Explain how social learning
applies to behavior and
mental processes.

7F64E1B297384896900850FED4866B69.description:
Social, Cognitive,
and Neurological
Factors in Learning

6B4C7E43E39D48EB9FF1E37FC23A6175.description:
The partial reinforcement schedules focus
on whether reinforcement is delivered on
a time-based schedule (fixed or variable
interval) or for the number of behaviors
performed (fixed or variable ratio).

1A03C0612D734AB99C59ADC7B221154D.description:
Continuous reinforcement schedules
deliver reinforcement for each and every
correct behavior.

C82D1690686448B6BAC12B45FBC6C23F.description:
The schedule with which reinforcement is
delivered can determine the strength of the
association between the consequence and the
response. The two main types of reinforcement
schedules are continuous and partial. Each
type of reinforcement behavior can be
graphed, resulting in a distinctive pattern
on the graph (e.g., fixed-interval schedule
produces a scalloped graph).

A98AE0C029A243C18310CEEF35901479.description:
Superstitious behavior occurs when
consequences reinforce unrelated behaviors.
Learned helplessness occurs when organisms
learn that they have no control over their
experience of aversive consequences in a
given situation.

D7167531E83B4AE6B1CAD6DA10747CD0.description:
Reinforcement can be used to shape behavior
(“shaping”) gradually through rewarding
successive approximations of the desired
behavior. Research with animals shows that
only certain behaviors can be shaped through
reinforcement (known as instinctive drift).

3795866C88434ADF878BDE92235310B0.description:
Reinforcement and punishment can be positive
or negative. Reinforcers can be primary or
secondary. Reinforcement discrimination and
generalization have been demonstrated in
studies of operant conditioning.

D82E1663837248FEA6C627C51C49A69B.description:
Operant conditioning focuses on associating
consequences (reinforcement and punishment)
with behaviors. The Law of Effect states that
behaviors with reinforcing consequences are
more likely to be repeated while behaviors with
punishing consequences are not as likely to be
repeated.

5B08010F6CB54F48927FF0ED9927590F.description:
Explain how operant
conditioning applies to
behavior and mental
processes.

C97E137235F5406CB282DEB9B7107F60.description:
Habituation occurs when organisms grow
accustomed to and exhibit a diminished
response to a repeated or enduring stimulus.

C047E4919A4A4F868C9D15FCFFD1F029.description:
Research on taste aversions, which are
acquired through classical conditioning,
demonstrates one-trial conditioning and
biological preparedness. One-trial learning
occurs when the association is acquired
through one pairing of the stimulus and
response and is not strengthened by further
pairings. Biological preparedness refers to
how animals are biologically predisposed to
learning certain stimulus-response pairings
more quickly than others.

A1DEF9916D5B45E39170E383BB4CBB4E.description:
Research has demonstrated that emotional
responses can be classically conditioned.
These findings form the basis of therapeutic
interventions for many mental disorders, such
as counterconditioning.

D666F9FACD8C416490B1D145AB686C21.description:
A CS can be used as a UCS in higher-order
conditioning.

C912FFD7C53F4433A3FC2480E89649A4.description:
Stimulus discrimination and generalization
have been demonstrated in studies of
classical conditioning.

27FBBCF6A0C14FC6A1AAC114B8A28562.description:
A CR can become extinct when the CS is
no longer paired with the UCS. A formerly
extinct CR can be spontaneously recovered
when the CS and UCS are paired together
again.

C0ABF904172148B6BC51A018BD5EF362.description:
The order of presentation of the CS
with the UCS is important to successful
acquisition.

FFA6CAE8EC764677BD45015584F3C707.description:
The unconditioned stimulus (UCS) elicits
an unconditioned response (UCR). This
response becomes the conditioned
response (CR) when it is performed in
response to the conditioned stimulus (CS).

63A0DA55583C46A09F214E29C572D6AF.description:
Classical conditioning focuses on the
association of one stimulus with another
stimulus to elicit a response. Learning the
association (also known as acquisition) involves
a series of steps that demonstrate principles of
associative learning.

DE2A7CA8F47F461F9778109B9BAB1DF3.description:
The behavioral perspective evolved from
theories about learning via conditioning.
Behaviorists have traditionally focused on
observable behavior to the exclusion of mental
processes.

0314ABA9C6274CF98B297E9F90233719.description:
Explain how classical
conditioning applies to
behavior and mental
processes.

D2DD90624BDC4D9B8A271660F22232B2.description:
Adolescents develop a sense of identity
for whom they will be as an adult through
the processes of achievement, diffusion,
foreclosure, and moratorium. Identity
development also includes processes for
developing identities such as racial/ethnic
identity, gender identity, sexual orientation,
religious identity, occupational identity, and
familial identity, often through considering
possible selves.

AC95E1233C924B32A535CBB7B535A322.description:
The experience of adverse childhood
experiences (ACEs) has effects on
relationships people form throughout the
lifespan. Sociocultural differences exist in what
is considered an ACE and how ACEs affect
outcomes people may experience.

5F3DE55A97E148FBA1CD1453DA1760AB.description:
The stage theory of psychosocial
development, which was a reconceptualization
of the psychosexual theory, proposes that
people must resolve psychosocial conflicts at
each stage of the lifespan. The stages are as
follows:

D9CC023B7A634DB0B6B0802A6FF7E77D.description:
Relationships with other adults result
in adults forming families or family-like
relationships that should provide mutual
support and care. Childhood attachment
styles can affect how adults form
attachments to other adults.

7466FC13A6714C30BE7FC46A4598A510.description:
Culture plays a role in determining when
adulthood begins and when major life
events occur (social clock). Some cultures
allow for a time of emerging adulthood as a
transition from adolescence to adulthood.

45B74ED92B9046448B2DBB92A00F3CAF.description:
Developmental psychologists study how adults
develop socially over time.

48B8105948C74D42815A0D12D32E582F.description:
Adolescents gradually rely more on peer
relationships as they age. As adolescents
interact with peers, they demonstrate
a type of egocentrism that is often
demonstrated via the imaginary audience
and the personal fable.

446533B766DC486B823F99D56B9AABC4.description:
Children engage with peers via play (parallel
and pretend).

2A167624C8654990AB87ED4B5512CDAE.description:
Developmental psychologists study how peer
relationships develop over time.

94155FE56E5E4632B14B7BE9A29BC763.description:
Studies with monkeys demonstrate
the importance of comfort over food in
attachment.

F16FA10525564D4F8BC32CE45859CF83.description:
Separation anxiety occurs when children
express heightened anxiety or fear when
away from a caregiver or in the presence of
a stranger.

93BE4F320F614774AE6C12B8B8F4FB8F.description:
Research has identified different attachment
styles demonstrated by infants and children,
which vary by culture. The types of attachment
infants and children display include secure and
insecure (avoidant, anxious, and disorganized).
Temperament is related to how children attach
to caregivers.

27C860B82D2D4120BCD4F87E5A2ED09F.description:
Research has identified different parenting
styles of caregivers, including authoritarian,
authoritative, and permissive. Cultural
differences exist in the ways these parenting
styles affect outcomes in caregivers and
children.

B25071C1D0274B6DAB3B5E95502214F9.description:
Chronosystem (the individual’s current
stage of life).

BF685B3DB44D4CD18546BE119A1C2208.description:
Macrosystem (cultural events that affect
the individuals and others around them)

6B4720EDE1A543828989AEE96DFB22D2.description:
Exosystem (indirect factors in an
individual’s life)

31B4CAADBEE14351B8F9B1406918A8F3.description:
Mesosystem (the relationships between
groups in the microsystem)

FC675014A1DE4C2198DBFC000813A0DC.description:
Microsystem (groups that have direct
contact with the individual)

B83B7B9C035A4AF2A1212DAC32AB8EEC.description:
The ecological systems theory explores
how the social environment influences
development. The five systems in this theory
are as follows:

D40B2F73E0C5419BB24D20D31231B890.description:
Explain how social
development relates
to behavior and mental
processes.

8D6C443D40574104AE0825913FF3CBA8.description:
In language development across all cultures,
people use nonverbal manual gestures (e.g.,
pointing) to communicate and develop formal
language through specific stages (cooing,
babbling, one-word stage, and telegraphic
speech). People learning a language often
make errors such as overgeneralization of
language rules as they learn.

1233503986344B5EB1AB77578A1746C3.description:
Explain how language
develops in humans.

274998B1F94947AF84C6C2F983D84A97.description:
Language is a shared (mutually agreed upon)
system of arbitrary symbols (often expressed
as and combined into phonemes, morphemes,
and semantics) that are rule-governed (via
grammar and syntax) and generative to
produce an infinity of ideas.

1B50F4F956B247FE9D733FD0AFC38065.description:
Explain how key
components of language
and communication apply
to behavior and mental
processes.

7AFC8B5FBAD845BFBDFFEC26BC68F052.description:
Adults experience changes in cognitive
capabilities as they progress through the
lifespan. Crystallized intelligence remains
relatively stable through adulthood while fluid
intelligence tends to wane as people age.
Cognitive disorders that affect adults include
dementia.

CF131898BBC74D2DA978F5554CB9B536.description:
According to Vygotsky, children are social
learners who learn through interacting with
and scaffolding by other people within
sociocultural contexts. Ideally, learning occurs
while the person is in their zone of proximal
development.

782C72AF8A3C4DE889B2A630EDD13C0F.description:
The formal operational stage occurs from
late childhood through adulthood. People in
this stage gain the ability to think abstractly
and hypothetically. Piaget proposed that
not all people achieve formal operational
thinking.

4080A42E08394E26A96598A9DA00708E.description:
The concrete operational stage occurs
from early through late childhood. Children
in this stage can generally correct the
cognitive errors made in the preoperational
stage and understand the world in logical,
realistic, and straightforward ways, but
struggle to think systematically.

3B91CC7D2CD640F7BC0C1410C214C269.description:
The preoperational stage occurs from
toddlerhood through early childhood.
Children become proficient in using mental
symbols and engage in pretend play. The
preoperational stage is identified more by
cognitive tasks children cannot perform
such as conservation and reversibility, or
by those they exhibit, such as animism and
egocentrism. Children begin to develop a
theory of mind during this stage.

DCD125BF48464B378B5E8FAA84804D93.description:
The sensorimotor stage occurs from
infancy through toddlerhood. Object
permanence develops during this stage.

3F368F3769F242E4B071901207975AD0.description:
According to Piaget, children develop schemas
via continuous and discontinuous processes
such as assimilation and accommodation.

9DDD81ECD72245FDA8EFA536350391C8.description:
Explain how theories of
cognitive development
apply to behavior and mental
processes.

8B626D8EA19544BC8090A2E1782C259A.description:
There are no required essential knowledge
statements for this learning objective.

BC25EF12D3894FA78A4ECCE7CF467B20.description:
Describe how sex and gender
influence socialization
and other aspects of
development.

4323BBB601884F28BC1B882B36CDD533.description:
Adulthood spans most of the lifespan and is
characterized by a general leveling off and then
a varying decline in reproductive ability (i.e.,
menopause), mobility, flexibility, reaction time,
and visual and auditory sensory acuity.

D97885A1C42D464A9A56A716B42E4BAA.description:
Explain how physical
development in adulthood
applies to behavior and
mental processes.

DCF7F533D80A482AB5D59D8BC4C7C1AF.description:
The main physical and psychological
milestones that occur in adolescence are
the adolescent growth spurt and puberty,
in which reproductive ability develops.
Adolescents develop primary and secondary
sex characteristics during this time, such as
menarche and spermarche.

F9DA3CCD05594A45B61D5DBFB44BB21C.description:
Explain how physical
development in adolescence
applies to behavior and
mental processes.

BC4C9F85463C430298E66930DF4DD86F.description:
Research suggests that critical or sensitive
periods in infancy and childhood have strong
developmental effects, especially for skills
such as language. Some non-human animals
will imprint on the first object they encounter
as a means of survival.

55B9ED4841FC4ACDAFB44F9AECABFF5D.description:
Research using the visual cliff apparatus
demonstrates an early ability in infants to
perceive depth and an innovative way to
assess infant responses.

F46BF690D4164F5D895B3B0D35E89492.description:
Infants possess reflexes, like the rooting
reflex, that indicate on-track physical and
psychological milestone development.

D3ACFB2D2E0E4311BEAC1072C68FCFA8.description:
Physical development in infancy and childhood
happens in generally the same order, but
the timing of the development can vary.
The development of fine and gross motor
coordination is among the major physical
and psychological milestones that define
infancy and childhood. These physical skills
develop as children mature, allowing children to
develop critical skills needed to become more
independent.

957AA532C5634942A32310D4CCD31861.description:
Explain how physical
development in infancy and
childhood apply to behavior
and mental processes.

0C2F82EEFE584099BC97BB590BA45A63.description:
Teratogens, maternal illness, genetic
mutations, hormonal, and environmental
factors can influence the major physical and
psychological milestones that occur during
prenatal development.

8E0B1303BD44474BBB9DD97E0C7D201C.description:
Explain how physical
development before birth
applies to behavior and
mental processes.

BA35D7381B5F4720857627A0991E66B6.description:
There are no required essential knowledge
statements for this learning objective.

530EFFEFDA8345E19DB9035EBE329AA4.description:
Describe ways crosssectional and longitudinal
research design methods
used in developmental
psychology inform
understanding about
behavior and mental
processes.

EF817F3CEEF447CE81F1EAF1E8525351.description:
Developmental psychology is concerned with
both chronological order of development and/
or thematic issues in development across
the lifespan. Thematic issues of interest
to developmental psychologists include
stability and change, nature and nurture, and
continuous and discontinuous stages of
development.

7BFE1AC0237D44C3A94209EE85A54394.description:
Explain how enduring themes
inform developmental
psychology.

7DE803E636EF408B9E61129E32935F84.description:
Themes and Methods
in Developmental
Psychology

5BB41F55026A4316A526AEAF4F09DCE2.description:
People’s beliefs about whether intelligence is
fixed from birth (fixed mindset) or malleable
due to experience (growth mindset) can affect
academic achievement.

55D589DD13BA4D0F9FC229CB7DC8DE85.description:
Some academic tests attempt to measure
what someone knows (achievement tests) or
predict how someone will perform in the future
(aptitude tests).

87F4790BE3B54908B8D27E88D8CBA6EE.description:
Explain how academic
achievement is measured
and experienced as
compared to intelligence.

F020EA51EBA1477198A3BD258A1C4E93.description:
Scores from intelligence tests have been
used to limit access to jobs, military ranks,
educational institutions, and immigration to the
US.

89046CE2C9444B9FA39D43FD43FA37EA.description:
IQ scores tend to vary more within a group than
between groups. Personal and sociocultural
biases can impact the interpretation
of individual IQ scores and the score’s
relationship with other outcomes. Poverty
discrimination and educational inequalities
can negatively influence intelligence scores
of individuals and societal groups around the
world.

795461A9F6394183AF24A81B65297358.description:
IQ scores across much of the world have
generally increased over time (Flynn Effect)
due to societal factors, such as higher
socioeconomic status and access to better
health care and better nutrition.

59B30CC2A8114F9EAA42941EB301A9CA.description:
Explain how systemic issues
relate to the quantitative
and qualitative uses of
intelligence assessments.

F5D9401DF3F94650A7F78987A16D987D.description:
Researchers strive to develop assessments of
intelligence that are socio-culturally responsive
to reduce stereotype threat and potential
inequity that may occur due to stereotype lift.

E550274322A1478099D3B88AB64B319F.description:
A test is considered reliable if it yields similar
results each time it is administered. Types of
reliability include test-retest and split-half.

1E654D121D11418B88FBDEAC69A114D7.description:
A test is considered valid if it measures
what it is designed to measure. Types of
validity include construct and predictive.

44FB302AE99F4FF3824CF59AEC9A3DC3.description:
A test is said to be standardized when it is
administered using consistent procedures
and environments.

8CFB826E5B3B4C5CA9059BCB1D4C6C16.description:
All psychological assessments, including
intelligence tests, should adhere to sound
psychometric principles to be considered useful.

3A3EA538A8F14A1AA9970CB1EF5141A2.description:
Early formal intelligence tests yielded an
intelligence quotient (IQ), which divided mental
age by chronological age. In modern times, IQ
scores are often used to identify students for
educational services.

3B03CBB8E069421E882EAE88801A0336.description:
Throughout history, consensus about how to
define and measure intelligence continues
to be elusive and can be subject to bias.
Researchers debate whether intelligence is
a general ability (called g) or is comprised of
multiple abilities.

6EF029123C54491EAFED68F07114FC1A.description:
Explain how modern and
historical theories describe
intelligence.

A5ADD46681EE415A81DCCA1174FE2D9D.description:
The accuracy of memories may be affected
by the misinformation effect, source amnesia,
or constructive memory (via memory
consolidation and imagination inflation).

FDDC2BB82D7A46E8A06F1E0C2F08F729.description:
Psychodynamic theorists believe that
information or memories can be forgotten to
defend the ego from distress (repression).

026E4F8B6F104EAEBFCA1BCD9023F2C9.description:
Many memories are difficult to retrieve due
to encoding failure, interference (proactive or
retroactive), or inadequate retrieval (i.e., tip-ofthe-tongue phenomenon).

BDD2C0D06EE348B5875BF16C6E176D3F.description:
The forgetting curve shows that time is a
significant factor in forgetting. Forgetting
occurs rapidly after initial learning and levels
off over time.

F16C1F164380465A8704B86A68C63C4A.description:
Explain possible reasons why
memory failure or errors may
occur.

E5EE59ADB4CA4D04B5BA16A639290BF9.description:
Successful retrieval is more likely when using
retrieval practice processes, including testing
effect and metacognition.

7B0F90CA76FE45F28DC72F41E343EEAA.description:
The process of memory retrieval can be
enhanced when people are in the same
environmental space (context-dependent
memory), mood (mood-congruent memory), or
physical state (state-dependent memory) as
they were when they encoded the information
to be retrieved.

36BABC5B118D40D2ABA88C82D5AC5353.description:
The process of memory retrieval occurs
through recall (remembering without cues) or
recognition (which relies on retrieval cues).

3805C3C5F14D4F40BB8BC26B18D0C5B4.description:
Explain how memory retrieval
processes get information
out of memory.

89BCE5DEFF224906AA4428C3471DC281.description:
Storage processes may be negatively affected
by physical impairment and developmental
limitations, such as amnesia (retrograde and
anterograde), Alzheimer’s disease, and infantile
amnesia.

10BCB6CE766E458882B27987BC8D0300.description:
Some people demonstrate highly superior
autobiographical memory which may indicate
that there are biological processes for superior
memory storage. Autobiographical memory
may also explain why memories connected to
our own lives or selves are more memorable.

0ECA113C22234BCF9A7264B246E9877D.description:
Storage may be prolonged by rehearsing
information over time (maintenance rehearsal).
Rehearsing information over time in ways that
promote meaning (elaborative rehearsal) helps
with memory retention.

28BB08893D7A4B64BC539EC1F91C4181.description:
Sensory memory, short-term memory, working
memory, and long-term memory are processes
that differ in storage duration, capacity, and
content.

B8E1544DAB73433AAAF40B9C0C6122DD.description:
Explain how memory storage
processes retain information
in memory.

4E3683F7E6F04625A8671BC53F09F0F3.description:
Encoding processes can be affected by the
order of how the information is presented,
called the serial position effect. The serial
position effect predicts that information
presented at the beginning of a list (primacy
effect) or the end of a list (recency effect)
will be more memorable than information
presented in the middle of a list.

FA5C43327CD34683B618FF6BD381152F.description:
The spacing effect is a process that can
cause significant differences in encoding and
memory consolidation depending on whether
the information is encoded all at once (massed
practice) or distributed over time (distributed
practice).

9AC2A3A603CE4BC3B384765B6CACBDBC.description:
Encoding can be improved by the process of
grouping information together into meaningful
chunks (“chunking”), categories, or hierarchies.

86A6044FBDF14107856A001780ABF614.description:
Mnemonic devices, such as method of loci, are
processes that aid in encoding information into
working and long-term memory.

B4D355E64D6B4C098E514EEE66026A81.description:
Encoding involves processes and strategies to
get information into memory. How information
is encoded can determine how effectively
information is stored and retrieved.

858E9C6ECBC84801AAF283F1DC973121.description:
Explain how different
encoding processes work to
get information into memory.

5BD3639048104619A37E22FF9AEDC066.description:
The levels of processing model proposes
that memory is encoded on three levels from
shallowest to deepest: structural, phonemic,
and semantic.

6B3D9DF010A048EA8642511BD435A517.description:
The multi-store model proposes three
interacting systems (sensory memory
[including iconic and echoic memory],
short-term memory, and long-term memory)
that information must pass through to be
remembered. This model focuses on the
impact of automatic and effortful processing
on memory encoding, storage, and retrieval.

EE38DB09117644828BE37A72420C5FA4.description:
The working memory model examines how our
primary memory system—working memory—
engages in a dynamic interaction with several
components, namely the central executive,
phonological loop, and visuospatial sketchpad,
to process information into long-term memory.

200F28D9A96549C88C989B460FFD8589.description:
Long-term potentiation, a process by which
synaptic connections between neurons
become stronger with frequent activation, is a
biological process for memory

4B77FB09BC8E4903849C188D590C98BE.description:
Prospective memory is a type of memory
related to future actions.

C8DF06F8A0214FF7BCF221C12A8E1AF2.description:
Implicit memory is more challenging to
describe or explain to others. Procedural
memory is a type of implicit memory for
procedures and processes.

4CF7ACBE59DA4829BC8E97A40E6CB6D2.description:
Explicit memory is a type of memory that
is more easily described or explained to
others. Types of explicit memory include
episodic and semantic.

38DA3CE4E977469CAB0172BA40B7EE02.description:
Memories for learned knowledge, events, and
experiences are differentiated by how they are
processed by, stored in, and retrieved by the
brain.

8E015468E9A245E7B75BF4EDEBBDA2A6.description:
Explain how the types,
structures, and processes of
memory work.

F5B362793FC64701934A1D08B7C4965D.description:
Creativity is a way of thinking that includes
generating novel ideas and engaging in
divergent (versus convergent) thinking.
Creative thinking is hindered by functional
fixedness.

B38D21E71A2B471F934F88A9475D99A3.description:
Executive functions are cognitive processes
that allow individuals to generate, organize,
plan, and carry out goal-directed behaviors and
experience critical thinking.

4A7D492679A3497592C8902DC7238381.description:
Cognitive processes such as gambler’s fallacy
and sunk-cost fallacy can hinder people from
making good decisions.

11D1A46F7B2B4A5380341D0561EDF3D1.description:
Decision making can be influenced by prior
experiences that were successful (mental
set) or circumstances surrounding a decision
(priming and framing).

328A76A682E643CC925F58986F6BCAFF.description:
Heuristics address problems by using mental
shortcuts to make judgments. Using heuristics
can lead to errors in judgment when decisions
are made according to prior expectations or
stereotypes (representativeness heuristic) or
recalling the first or most vivid example that
comes to mind (availability heuristic).

5AAA68C53B25426D86457DF6F51ADE5C.description:
Algorithms address problems by attempting
all possible solutions until the correct one is
found.

113464134EA44ECF994669803F9A2619.description:
People form and modify schemas, or
frameworks for thinking, through assimilation
(taking in new information but not changing
the schema in light of it) and accommodation
(taking in new information and changing the
schema to incorporate the new information).

843B8360BC1A4C19A7CFB039950F5B57.description:
Concepts form the basis of thought.
Prototypes are the ideal example for any given
concept.

49317D2131DA457D931660DDCEA6D17A.description:
Explain how psychological
concepts and theories
account for thinking,
problem-solving, judgment,
and decision-making.

E12C7476C7C94D959D8B51BE57DEEE8D.description:
Apparent movement can be visually perceived
even when objects are not actually moving.

B84984F9A7DA4D3699C816772E341F85.description:
Visual perceptual constancies maintain the
perception of an object even when the images
of the object in the visual field change.

1B99D0D157E64FECB10025E6579AEFB5.description:
Monocular depth cues (relative clarity, relative
size, texture gradient, linear perspective, and
interposition) give the illusion of depth on flat
or two-dimensional surfaces.

4208DF91DD544D43AEEAF807D973DDB0.description:
Binocular depth cues of retinal disparity (the
difference between the images projecting onto
the retina) and convergence (the merging of
the retinal images by the brain) utilize images
from each eye to provide perception of depth.

CEAA1AC59763407B86B5B613425B24EA.description:
Explain how visual perceptual
processes produce correct
or incorrect interpretations of
stimuli.

131F32BEF5AF4750BAC6FED608F0F233.description:
Inattention can lead to a type of “blindness”
to aspects of the environment. Change
blindness occurs when changes to the
environment are not perceived due to
inattention.

C71AF274AF32482BBCEA44574A3EAC21.description:
Some experiences of attention can be
selective, such as with the cocktail party
effect, where people attend to mentions
of their names or specific topics in loud or
distracting environments.

177941F6EBF043E485B5599F3B5CF3F2.description:
Attention is an interaction of sensation and
perception that is affected by internal and
external processes.

98A33CCC2DF54B098FE1F27DBBB98085.description:
Perceptual principles proposed by Gestalt
psychology (closure, figure and ground,
proximity, and similarity) help explain how
humans organize their perceptual world.

D48EE32558624CAAAB7F188D373ED8B8.description:
Contexts, experiences, and cultural
experiences and expectations are external
factors that filter perceptions of the world.

F755A60843024AA4AE2352EAE38E4F5B.description:
Schemas and perceptual sets are internal
factors that filter perceptions of the world.

008B55D734034165BF31EAEED1DE4037.description:
Perception is influenced by whether one
primarily relies on external sensory information
(bottom-up processing) or internal prior
expectations (top-down processing).

CE5106193F894E03A28A58F11336C1BF.description:
Explain how internal and
external factors influence
perception.

DFFB7F5E91304BAB808ED922D95106FC.description:
Kinesthesis the sense of one’s body
movement. Kinesthesis allows the body to
move in coordinated ways without having
to look at the various parts of the body as it
moves.

3E997838D9DA4A05BE18D82DC2EDBA12.description:
The vestibular sense controls balance and is
primarily detected by the semicircular canals
and structures in the brain.

5E70B066140846409CDB58B1E7CEED5E.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions that maintain
balance (vestibular) and
body movement (kinesthetic)
relate to behavior and mental
processes.

86918A0C447B4D39A237B1EC08B9A47D.description:
Pain is processed both in the body and in the
brain. Gate control theory is one attempt to
describe the complexities of pain. Phantom
limb sensation occurs when people who have
lost limbs report sensation or pain where the
limb used to be.

DA1BF519D3864EB1841A59342F9D0894.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of the pain
sensory system relate
to behavior and mental
processes.

3B0C434F293748ACB0ED67F063E1506A.description:
Structures within the skin and brain process
and/or transduce touch stimuli. The sensation
of “hot” is produced by the activation of warm
and cold receptors in the skin.

31C76757A4AC4CD9B44C8BB085BCA0D6.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of the touch
sensory system relate
to behavior and mental
processes.

0B3425B79BC8431EA633FDE993773E64.description:
The chemical senses interact to create the
sensation of taste. Without the sense of smell,
taste sensations are either muted or not
experienced.

E9855F684EFD45F390BB5FC6469B9FAD.description:
Structures in the tongue, mouth, and brain
process and/or transduce basic tastes. The
number of taste receptors on the tongue is
related to how sensitive people are to tastes,
classifying them as supertasters, medium
tasters, or nontasters.

70522B0EE2A3448DBF09B1CDAA50952E.description:
Gustation is the sense of taste, and types of
tastes include sweet, sour, salty, bitter, umami,
and oleogustus.

7EF78D6364124DB2AB527E08A98EC4DB.description:
Structures in the nose and brain process and/
or transduce olfactory stimuli. Smell is the
only sense not processed first in the thalamus
of the brain. Pheromones produce chemical
messages for the olfactory system.

67D1665801E74D288B8F4ABF237677C0.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of the chemical
sensory systems relate
to behavior and mental
processes.

DB86E9AC88D341F3B45A8DC6CAF86218.description:
Hearing difficulties can result from aging and
various kinds of damage to auditory structures.
Types of hearing loss include conduction
deafness and sensorineural deafness.

C73028DF19074585A9DE99FD76FAE796.description:
Sound localization describes how we identify
where sounds in our environment are coming
from.

88BC8CA95D024D6498AF0AFE5D6A73F8.description:
Theories that help explain pitch perception
include place theory, volley theory, and
frequency theory.

B2E74563028F46D5BF028185F6FC6326.description:
Sound occurs through the movement of air
molecules at different wavelengths (called
pitch) and amplitudes (called loudness).

E0EDCB9F37EF4B10BD8C2DAACBC35045.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of the auditory
sensory system relate
to behavior and mental
processes.

959852660718486290EB3F198490C21B.description:
Damage to parts of the brain responsible for
vision (mainly the occipital lobes) can result
in disorders such as prosopagnosia (face
blindness) and blindsight.

E6732B8FE1384994A2C9AD5EFEB203D0.description:
Color vision deficiency involves damage
or irregularities to one or more cones
or ganglion cells (red/green, blue/
yellow). Color vision deficiency includes
dichromatism or monochromatism.

050AF2DF9B604CC1A91F360E9A4E62B3.description:
Afterimages result when certain ganglion
cells in the retina are activated while others
are not. The ganglion cells involved in this
opponent process are red/green, blue/
yellow/ and black/white.

5D0A97906C0C42359DD3DF9598845C2F.description:
Photoreceptor cells located in the fovea of
the eye that process color and detail are
called cones. Researchers have identified
blue (detecting short wavelengths), green
(detecting medium wavelengths) and red
(detecting long wavelengths) cones in the
retina.

D05C75598CB74F00B80484D2A24EF789.description:
Color vision is explained by both the
trichromatic theory and the opponent-process
theory.

0233493ECEA547759ADE61DDFA121AEA.description:
Cells that lie in the periphery of the eye
and detect shapes and movement, but not
color, are called rods. These cells are mainly
activated in low-light environments. These cells
play a role in light and dark adaptation.

257777E4382346BBA13BA8931E3DEFAA.description:
Visual stimuli are focused onto the retina by
the lens via a process called accommodation.
When this process is altered, nearsightedness
or farsightedness can result.

9561A9FC908946BEAD3AB6F9A9561A13.description:
The retina is the photosensitive surface at
the back of the eye. Cells in the retina capture
visual information that is transduced to the
brain for processing. Evidence of incomplete
images captured by the retina is demonstrated
by the presence of the blind spot, where the
visual nerve exits the eye. The brain fills in
the gaps in the incomplete retinal images to
perceive a relatively complete picture of the
world.

DFA68748F28241BCAAB8A9F87D609E70.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of the visual
sensory system relate
to behavior and mental
processes.

B7A292D0571942B49D55FC8E68C2588B.description:
The sensory systems constantly work together
in a process called sensory interaction.
Synesthesia is an experience of sensation in
which one system of sensation is experienced
through another.

3FE0DD358B3F4084B0861FD0FBA82D3A.description:
Detection of change in stimuli or diminished
sensitivity to stimuli can be explained by
the just-noticeable difference and sensory
adaptation. Weber’s law describes the degree
to which stimuli need to be different for the
difference to be detected.

1661B5860E664E31B3772DEC5E87D6DF.description:
Sensation is the process of detecting
information from the environment that meets
a certain threshold and transducing stimuli
into neurochemical messages for processing
(perception) in the brain. The absolute
threshold occurs when a stimulus can be
detected at least 50% of the time.

3371DA48796248E6AC6C41113C50E85F.description:
Explain how the process
of sensation is related
to behavior and mental
processes.

4043D0AC98F74BD49BE058F1882F5CEB.description:
Many disorders interrupt healthy sleep, and
their effects on waking behavior and health
vary. Sleep disruptions can affect physical and
cognitive performance during wakefulness.
Treating sleep disorders and following
regular schedules for sleeping can improve
waking performance and overall well-being.
Disorders commonly studied in introductory
psychology include insomnia, narcolepsy, REM
sleep behavior disorder, sleep apnea, and
somnambulism.

8B77DCB42555401B9A983712063C4B86.description:
Memory consolidation and restoration are
current theories about why sleep occurs.
These theories suggest that sleep is useful
for organizing and consolidating memories or
restoring depleted resources used throughout
a given day

D2F46CC8DB6E46518D5F579A0FB10DE1.description:
Theories regarding the structure and function
of dreams include activation-synthesis and
consolidation theory.

705AB71B6B88491B881D82A229C9B970.description:
REM sleep is considered paradoxical
because it produces waves similar to
wakefulness, but the body is at its most
relaxed. Dreaming typically occurs in REM
sleep. The frequency of REM sleep typically
increases as the cycle progresses. When
deprived of REM sleep, REM rebound can
occur.

178F5A97BDBB484E8459EC4C091C8D8D.description:
NREM sleep occurs in Stages 1 through 3
and decreases in duration throughout the
cycle. Hypnogogic sensations occur as one
enters Initial Stage 1 sleep.

47255BF98BB7475C93F92BEE61B9AC04.description:
The stages of sleep are identified by their
specific EEG patterns.

058B6958A5684E66B04AF42FE4A2E4E5.description:
The sleep/wake cycle is a circadian rhythm,
which in humans is about a 24-hour cycle.
Jet lag and shift work are disruptions of the
circadian rhythm.

E2BE877AC0194EDD84832A44CC591663.description:
Consciousness has varying levels of
awareness of thoughts, feelings, behavior,
and events in individuals’ internal and external
worlds. Sleep and wakefulness are two types of
consciousness.

BA82146745AF4FA89127D3B5E96DDABF.description:
Explain how the sleep/wake
cycle affects behavior and
mental processes throughout
the day and night.

C227A70319CD435FBE205308EEDFED89.description:
Research on the brain is done using scans
(including EEG and fMRI), case studies, and
surgical procedures (such as lesioning) to
promote understanding of how the different
structures of the brain work and how the brain
functions together as a whole.

7EE78F55311A4CB18D5D4E0B1948C8ED.description:
Brain plasticity is the ability of the brain
to rewire itself or modify or create new
connections throughout development and
generally allows for the function of a damaged
part of the brain to be assumed by a different
part of the brain.

ECB0CA7181A14D659605B1ED389280D9.description:
Researchers test for cortex specialization
with split-brain patients by showing
information in each visual field, taking
advantage of the brain’s contralateral
hemispheric organization.

2F29BE502A7044A3B5C5A231362220B6.description:
Areas of the brain that affect language are
typically located in the left hemisphere
and include Broca’s area (responsible for
speech production) and Wernicke’s area
(responsible for speech comprehension).
Damage to these parts of the brain can lead
to aphasia.

EB29DEFF1E8649C583B75C69C03CA3A1.description:
Split brain research, achieved by severing
the corpus callosum (often a treatment for
severe epilepsy), reveals that the right and left
hemispheres of the brain may specialize in
different activities and functions.

A925C4CFB36C46C8BBD60E37137C157E.description:
The frontal lobes, located just behind
the forehead, generally control linguistic
processing, higher-order thinking, and
executive functioning, especially in the
prefrontal cortex. The motor cortex is
located at the rear of the frontal lobes and
controls most types of skeletal movement.

F22311AF27004FFCB1EC9050ADE0C22A.description:
The parietal lobes generally control
association areas, which process
and organize information, and the
somatosensory cortex, which processes
touch sensitivity. These lobes are located
near the back crown of the brain.

8FD023C17AEB4B228FEDFB9ADC9FF39D.description:
The temporal lobes generally control
auditory and linguistic processing and are
located on the sides of the brain.

172A60972EAC48748CB651FA049B87B7.description:
The occipital lobes generally control visual
information processing and are located in
the rear of the brain.

5E82CD076A5646CCA4B680FBBA42809C.description:
The cerebral cortex is divided into two
hemispheres and includes the limbic system
(thalamus, hypothalamus, pituitary gland,
hippocampus, amygdala), corpus callosum, and
the lobes of the cortex.

E82B313F6B9B4C7391D3315673FC77B2.description:
The cerebellum generally controls coordination
of muscle movement, balance, and some forms
of procedural learning.

D5A4CD197AA54028ADD3289C195DFD52.description:
The reticular activating system and the brain’s
reward center generally control some voluntary
movement, eye movement, and some types of
learning, cognition, and emotion.

F713CF4C1E1D4341A1341773AE36DB87.description:
The brain stem (including the medulla)
generally controls basic functioning such as
breathing and heart rate.

5260AD4E8AEA47CDBD449050DC29AD0E.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of the brain
apply to behavior and mental
processes.

DCB836CE4FCE4EF18A6C8539C1EEBFC0.description:
Opioids, such as heroin, typically act as
pain relievers.

3941469E2D5C4520B099BC5E203396C2.description:
Hallucinogens, such as marijuana, typically
cause distortions in perception and/or
cognition.

F5AC9B1A67B9409385DF87AD39991E59.description:
Depressants, such as alcohol, typically
cause decreased neural activity.

1DD5F03819664746B9605B6758574DDB.description:
Stimulants, such as caffeine and cocaine,
typically cause increased neural activity.

A96AD6C15C814D9A91E754A625179944.description:
Psychoactive drugs have psychological and
physiological effects.

575957B839B04A58A7E5AA29A6216AF2.description:
Psychoactive drugs can influence
neurotransmitter function in various ways
throughout the neural communication process.
Some act as agonists which encourage
neural firing. Some act as antagonists which
discourage neural firing. Some act as reuptake
inhibitors which block the reabsorption of
neurotransmitters back into the cell.

36838AB9CD8C4A09962C48E06008F4F0.description:
Explain how psychoactive
drugs affect behavior and
mental processes.

ACBC12EB86EA4FEAB4252824D8D680F9.description:
Outside of the nervous system, hormones
perform actions similar to neurotransmitters.
Hormones related to behavior and mental
processes for study in AP Psychology are
limited to adrenaline, leptin, ghrelin, melatonin,
and oxytocin.

2D66819B5C124B0490898691DA1777BA.description:
Each neurotransmitter has specific
function(s) related to behavior and mental
processes, which may depend on the
neurotransmitter’s location in the nervous
system. Neurotransmitters generally
communicate either excitatory (making an
action potential more likely) or inhibitory
(making an action potential less likely)
messages. Neurotransmitters related to
behavior and mental processes for study in AP
Psychology are limited to dopamine, serotonin,
norepinephrine, glutamate, GABA, endorphins,
substance p, and acetylcholine.

285091039A3F4C2C93539184C1A76535.description:
The process of neural transmission most
commonly occurs in an orderly, systematic
way and involves the all-or-nothing principle,
depolarization, refractory period, resting
potential, reuptake, and threshold. Disruptions
to this process could lead to disorders such as
multiple sclerosis or myasthenia gravis.

24AEA1FDF99B47A08EDCDB04C9B0B0DC.description:
Explain how the basic
process of neural
transmission is related
to behavior and mental
processes.

78345AD045EC4587B9DB9040CE9C3F4F.description:
Psychoactive drug use can lead to tolerance
and/or addiction. Addiction can create
significant withdrawal symptoms if the
psychoactive drugs are no longer consumed.

58F17B24B56A4E03AF99C54922D932CB.description:
In the spinal cord, the reflex arc demonstrates
how neurons within the central and peripheral
nervous systems work together to respond to
stimuli. Three types of neurons work together
in the spinal cord to create a reflex arc: sensory
neurons, motor neurons, and interneurons.

72116D9A9604442D86DDA3A8DA5B0442.description:
Two common types of neural cells in the
brain are neurons (neural cells that transmit
information) and glial cells (cells that provide
structure, insulation, communication, and
waste transport). These types of cells form
the basis of the nervous system and are the
building blocks of all behavior and mental
processes.

8252D867647341E88C548811A0F1307A.description:
Explain how the structures
and functions of typical
neurons in the central
nervous system affect
behavior and mental
processes.

7B2ADB861BC64CFC87E50615A0327B63.description:
The somatic nervous system governs
processes that are voluntary.

6173EBC990CB46858789A2C936A1028C.description:
The autonomic nervous system governs
processes that are involuntary and includes
the parasympathetic and sympathetic
nervous systems.

97C08623F37E41418AE7155DBEF53BF9.description:
The peripheral nervous system relays
messages from the central nervous system
to the rest of the body and includes the
autonomic and somatic nervous systems.

1682C2AE4F46470397304963C4ECEADF.description:
The central nervous system includes the
brain and the spinal cord and interacts with all
processes in the body.

A4189189A2EE477D9461B8ACAF912400.description:
Differentiate among the
subsystems of the human
nervous system and their
functions.

18A9A1E2E4D644C1B3256C598BF24E91.description:
Research on the effects of genes on individual
behavior and mental processes is often
conducted using twin studies, family studies,
and adoption studies.

64321AF143F244899B7669A5F2B9FF87.description:
The evolutionary perspective explores how
natural selection affects the expression of
behavior and mental processes to increase
survival and reproductive success. Some
theorists have sought to apply principles of
the evolutionary perspective in ways that
discriminate against others (eugenics).

021C68CED2CC439183C97D43E962409E.description:
Environmental factors, or “nurture,”
refers to the external factors that one
experiences, such as family interactions or
education.

BEB290B72E1C4BDD905E913A5F217745.description:
Heredity, or “nature,” refers to genetic or
predisposed characteristics that influence
physical, behavioral, and mental traits and
processes.

42993473994A4973AA51DFDEB162CE50.description:
Heredity and environmental factors interact to
shape behavior and mental processes.

30114440E14D451AABFB875599EFF9AB.description:
Explain the relationship
between heredity and
environment in shaping
behavior and mental
